cleaned_comment: yes, in Spain we have a situation that is different than with them in Germany. So traditionally, we have always been an immigration country. In this respect, it's the case with us that in Spain you don't quite see yet what the effects are that you've already had in Germany. And we are now also experiencing them in England, for example, with the Pakistanis or in Paris with the people from Algeria. As a result, it's quite important for us to get to know their experiences. Because as you just said, the immigrants who went to France, they were Spanish, they were Italian. But now that we're all in the EU, we don't see ourselves as immigrants anymore. So for example there are still Spaniards who go to France to work because we have the common market. And now we only talk about migration, that is, transfers, for example, that workers go from one country to another and so on. And of course it's also true that we have, let's say, come closer together. We are all in Europe now, and we differ from those who come from outside Europe, for example the Africans of the Near East. For example, they have a religion that is somewhat antagonistic to ours. And there is now the following: finally I had the chance to stay during a time in Morocco. And of course we were afraid of the unknown and of this society, which is so different from ours. And I had the opportunity now to live there and I suddenly understood why they want to come to Europe. You know why they want to. Because nobody has money. But they all want a satellite dish, or they want to have all the European channels. And then they see the beautiful houses, then they see the beautiful parks and a world that seems almost an ideal world. Yes, and now they have that right on their doorstep, so to speak. And there it's very difficult for someone to see that, in their own situation. For example, in Median or in Fez. And there you have the feeling that regressions are being made, so it's almost like going back to the Middle Ages. And the big fish, they swim right in front of the door. And otherwise you only have mosquitoes. Or flies. And if you buy a leather vest, for example, it stinks like anything. And the Arabs work under this inhumane milieu and they see what we live there, then of course they feel like coming to us. And I am the first to understand how they feel.   but of course we can't take in the whole world. But you understand the reasons why they want to come to us. They all have television and that's interesting to see by the way. In a country where it also has poverty neighborhoods, that they all have satellite dishes. And they all try to have television, of course. And so globalization is spreading to the farthest corners. And I can tell you that in the Atlas Mountains near Marrakech, for example, there is a small residential area that is medieval. But the people, they offer then their specialties and so, but all have TVs with satellite dishes and see what's on, for example, in Madrid. And all of Africa has seen how Madrid played against Barcelona, for example. So you're really globalized. So it goes all the way to the last corners of the world. And of course I don't want to go on for too long here, but this whole issue has become so complicated. And of course, you can't close all the borders now. You would really have to put up a guardian every 200 meters, even in Amelia, in this little enclave they really put up grids that are four meters high and still people try to climb over them.
speech: [33:20] ja, in Spanien haben wir eine Situation, die anders ist, als bei ihnen in Deutschland. Also traditionellerweise sind wir immer ein Einwanderungsland gewesen. Aber da wir jetzt alle in die EU gehören, sehen wir uns jetzt nicht mehr als Einwanderer. Und man spricht jetzt nur noch von Migration, also von Transfers, zum Beispiel dass eben Arbeitskräfte von einem Land ins andere gehen und so weiter. Wir sind jetzt alle in Europa und unterscheiden uns damit von denen, die von ausserhalb von Europa kommen, zum Beispiel die Vorderafrikaner. Die haben zum Beispiel eine Religion, die unserer etwas antagonistisch gegenübersteht. Und da gib es jetzt folgendes: letztlich hatte ich die Chance, mich während einer Zeit in Marokko aufzuhalten. Und wir hatten natürlich Angst vor dem Unbekannten und dieser Gesellschaft, die ja so anders ist als die unsere. Und ich hatte die Möglichkeit jetzt, dort zu leben und ich habe auf einmal verstanden, warum die nach Europa kommen wollen. Man weiss, warum sie wollen. Weil keiner Geld hat. Alle wollen aber eine Parabolantenne, oder wollen alle europäischen Kanäle haben. Und dann sehen sie die schönen Häuser, dann sehen sie die wunderschönen Parks und eine Welt, die fast eine Idealwelt scheint. Ja und das haben sie jetzt direkt vor der Tür sozusagen. Und da ist es sehr schwierig für jemanden, der das sieht, in seiner eigenen Situation. Zum Beispiel in Median oder in Fes. Und da hat man das Gefühl, dass Rückschritte gemacht werden, also als wäre es fast so als würde man ins Mittelalter. Und die dicken Fische, die schwimmen direkt vor der Tür. Und die Araber arbeiten unter diesem unmenschlichen Milieu und die sehen also, was wir da leben, dann haben die natürlich Lust, zu uns zu kommen. Und damit verbreitet sich die Globalisierung bis in die hinterste Ecke hinein. Und ich kann ihnen sagen, also im Atlasgebirge, in der Nähe von Marrakesch, da gibt es zum Beispiel eine kleine Wohnsiedlung, die mittelalterlich ist. Aber die Leute, die bieten dann ihre Spezialitäten an und so, aber alle haben Fernseher mit Parabolantennen und sehen, was zum Beispiel in Madrid läuft. Und ganz Afrika hat erlebt, wie zum Beispiel Madrid gegen Barcelona da gespielt hat. Man ist da also wirklich globalisiert. Also bis in die letzten Zipfel der Welt hinein geht das. cleaned_comment: Maybe you also have to take into consideration the immigration structure. Let's talk about legal immigration, so especially family reunion. So we're talking about children, wives, the family being reunited, I think that's a human right. So I would say that this was uncontested. As far as the qualification of training is concerned, every country can offer training to its citizens, to its potential citizens, but there has to be a will; it has to be known whether this will exists or not and whether integration is lived or not. It can work well, it can't work. There are some examples in Austria where it works very well, but there are other examples that completely fail [...]. So, highly qualified people can immigrate without any problem, there is a system that exists but it is also very, very difficult and there are quite important obstacles. We have to ask ourselves in general: Where are we going? Do we need immigrants, do we treat them respectfully, regardless of their background, or is it a political calculation, do we want to form an opinion against immigration in general? The media make me think that it is more like that; they really try to form an opinion against immigrants, even highly qualified ones, especially against human beings who simply need our help, so asylum seekers. And in Austria, the climate is such that we try to deny help to these people, which I find serious. And here I plead for an active intervention of the European Union in this field.

À ce qui concerne la qualification de formation, chaque pays peut offrir une formation à ses citoyens, à ses citoyens potentiels, mais il faut y avoir une volonté ; il faut savoir si cette volonté existe ou non et si on vit l’intégration ou non. Ça peut bien fonctionner, ça ne peut pas fonctionner. Il y a en Autriche quelques exemples ou cela fonctionne très bien mais il y a d’autres exemples qui foirent complètement [...]. Donc, des personnes hautement qualifiés peuvent immigrer sans problème, il y a un système qui existe mais ça aussi c’est très très difficile et il existe des obstacles assez importants. Il faut se poser la question en règle générale : Où va-t-on ? Donc est-ce qu’on a besoin des immigrés, est-ce qu’on les traite de manière respectueuse, indépendamment de leur formation ou est-ce que c’est un calcule politique, est-ce qu’on veut former de l’opinion contre l’immigration en générale. Les médias me font penser que c’est plutôt cela ; on essaye vraiment de former une opinion contre les immigrés, même hautement qualifié, surtout contres des personnes humains qui ont tout simplement besoin de notre aide, donc les chercheurs d’asile, les demandeurs d’asile. Et en Autriche justement, le climat est tel que nous essayons de refuser de l’aide à ces personnes, ce que je trouve grave. Et là, je plaide en faveur d’une intervention active de l’Union Européenne dans ce domaine. [45 :34]

cleaned_comment: Yes, in France, there has always been immigration. In the 20th century, there were in particular the Polish for a certain period of time, a little later the Italians, the Portuguese and the Spanish, before the Second World War. This did not pose any problems, in the sense that people came to France to work, not necessarily to die, at the end of their normal life. They came to work because there was more work in France at that time than in their country of origin. But they tried to assimilate, to integrate into the host country. And it was relatively easy because the cultures were relatively close. And from all that we have heard since the beginning, people are not opposed to immigration, but we feel that the problem that arises, even if the word has not been pronounced, is that many immigrants are of Muslim faith and that precisely, that makes a very different culture. So, it's true, it's a problem, we mustn't hide   [...] our faces. Most immigrants try to live like they do in their country of origin, others do not. But there is indeed a problem that many people feel every day and this problem, in fact, makes them against immigration in that sense. That's the first point. Second point, it is true that by accepting immigrants in the European Union, we somehow impoverish the countries of origin. And for that we can't do anything, it's not us who go and get them, it's them who come of their own free will and I don't see how to do it differently. But it is certain and even last night, I saw on French television a program about French doctors who had operated on children in Togo and the Togolese doctor said that there are more Togolese doctors from the Paris region than Togolese doctors in Togo themselves. But that is not our fault. It is a choice they make and I do not see how we can oppose it.
speech: [11 :58] Oui, en France, il y a toujours eu une immigration. Au 20ième siècle, il y a eu particulier les polonais pour une certaine période, un peu plus tard les italiens, les portugais et les espagnols, avant la seconde guerre mondiale. Ça n’a pas posé des problèmes, dans se sens que les gens venaient en France pour travailler, pas obligatoirement pour y mourir, en fin de leur vie normale. C’était ils venaient travailler parce qu’il y avait plus de travail dans cette époque en France que dans leur pays d’origine. Mais ils essayaient de s’assimiler, de s’intégrer dans le pays d’accueil. Et c’était relativement facile parce que les cultures étaient quand même relativement proches. Et de tous ce qu’on a entendu depuis le début,  les gens ne sont pas opposés à l’immigration, mais on sent que le problème qui se pose, même si le mot n’a pas été prononcer, c’est que beaucoup d’immigrés sont de confession musulmane et que justement, ça fait une culture très différente. Alors, c’est vrai, c’est un problème, il ne faut pas se voiler [13 :10] [00 :00] […] la face. La plupart des immigrés essaie de vivre comme on vit dans le pays d’origine, d’autres ne le font pas. Mais il y a effectivement un problème et que beaucoup de gens ressentent tous les jours et se problème, en fait, fait qu’ils sont contre l’immigration au sens là. Ça c’est un premier point. Deuxième point, c’est vrai qu’en acceptant des immigrés dans l’Union Européenne, on appauvrit en quelque sort les pays d’origine. Et pour ça on y peut rien, ce n’est pas nous qui allons les chercher, c’est eux qui viennent de leur propre gré et je ne vois pas comment le faire différemment. Mais c’est certain et même hier soir, je voyais à la télévision française une émission sur des médecins français qui avait opérer des enfants au Togo et le médecin à profession de médicine togolais disait qu’il y a plus de médecins togolais de la région Parisienne que de médecin togolais au Togo eux mêmes. cleaned_comment: Our geographical situation in our islands is obviously different from that of the peninsula, we have not experienced problems with legal immigrants, who have been established for many years and the foreigners in our country have accepted and respected our customs in a way in the religious schools, even if they do not follow religious activities, but in no way have they wanted or asked that we remove our religious symbols. People have their own celebrations apart. But the question that arises now is not the legal immigration, but obviously the clandestine. Those who arrive without being asked, without being necessary. I don't know what happened; there was a month and a half or two months without any makeshift boats arriving here, although the method is favourable. So I am very surprised. But now we are in a situation - I don't know if we don't want to, but I speak for them - where they arrive in such a lamentable state. We can't even help them, they go straight to the internment center. Why did they leave   their country of origin. Why are they poor there? Well, they left because they can't live. So, it's a difficult situation to find a solution there. In the Canary Islands, the question of immigration is really serious because there is illegal immigration; the immigrants manage to flow the controls and then, above, obviously, there is delinquency and all the consequences of delinquency. And if they were welcomed, if they had any opportunity it would be better. And, again, we come to the question of work and there is no work for these people. Yes, they have priority in the nurseries, in the schools, for social housing and there are young people who are on the list for an apartment to start a family and they don't succeed. But a foreigner, an immigrant, can't do anything easily. And therefore it will create ill-being. The solution which is right, I do not know. But that's why we're here, to find a solution.

Es wurde gesagt, um den Leuten es einfacher zu machen, in Deutschland zu immigrieren, wollen wir sie versetzen, wollen wir sie zwischen den Deutschen reinsetzen, dass sie mit der Sprache, mit der Kultur mit aufwachsen können, dass wir ihre Kultur übernehmen. Aber ich sage, alle Einwanderer, die legal oder illegal kommen, die illegal kommen, die kommen nicht umsonst. Das wurde schon von Ana richtig gesagt, irgendwo fehlt es in den Ländern und sie kommen ja nicht umsonst illegal zu uns rein. Also sollten diese alle, wie sie kommen möchten in den einzelnen Ländern, zuerst bereit sein, Sprache im Text und im Ausdruck zu erlernen. Dann sind sie bestimmt auch in vielen Ländern willkommen. Willkommen sind die, die für das Bruttosozialprodukt was unternehmen wollen, die das Land nach vorne bringen wollen. Und die, die sich nur auf den Knochen, so geht es wahrscheinlich allen, ausruhen möchten, nämlich nur die sozialen Aspekte in Kauf nehmen und dankend annehmen, wirtschaftlich davon profitieren wollen, die braucht wahrscheinlich jedes Land gar nicht so. Und das ist schon einmal ein Problem, was eigentlich die Politiker in ganz Europa – und wenn wir noch enger zusammenwachsen wollen und sollen, was natürlich phantastisch wäre, da muss man diese Sachen auch mal ansprechen bei den Politikern. cleaned_comment: Yeah, I think as far as immigration is concerned, it's not politically correct to really say what you see. You just can't express your opinion and then it's politically incorrect. I come from Spain, from a small village, and there we don't have immigrants. But when I visit a good friend in Madrid, for example, there are certain neighborhoods; when you get off the subway there, you are not in Spain. You don't know the language, you don't know the cultures, it's really anything but Spain. You really don't know where you are anymore. And that's not all. The people who have come to Spain from different countries simply don't want to integrate. They want to speak their language, they want to continue living their culture. For example, I was at another friend's house, there was a street where children used to play, where the older people played chess outside, and now there are no more children. I said, what's going on there? No, you can't sit there anymore. You can't sit there anymore. There are people living there now, they are Moroccans or North Africans, and if you want to sit down there, you have to pay a euro. And you can't go to parks anymore, that's no longer possible. And that is of course quite terrible, if you have to say that, but these immigrants are disturbing. And of course we can say, well, they have a right and of course they have advantages, but they just don't want to integrate. We are not very many in my village, about 6,500 inhabitants, there is a family that comes from China and I have a friend who comes from Ecuador. And that's all. They are all non-Spanish. For example, I have a friend who works in a restaurant and now he earns the same as he did 25 years ago because the salaries were always reduced, of course. cleaned_comment: So, what I could understand when I worked in these two organizations, one of which was rather the reception of immigrants, the other rather in the control of immigration. These rules are more important than the rules set by the EU, which is more concerned with the movement of immigration within the borders. What I could see is that in France, for example, there was a period when people arriving in France were required to sign a contract that included learning the French language. To facilitate integration. Today we have radically changed our approach, that is to say that we ask that people who wish to immigrate to France be able to prove in their own country that they are French. So in fact there are movements of agents of the French state that are in countries that are identified as countries for seeing immigration applications and it is in these countries, when we control for example the language, so that is a first criterion but of course there is another criterion that was posed more recently by the French government which is to identify the professional skills. It's a little bit like the euro question, which effectively means choosing between [...] the immigration population, which is what we need in France today. But there is another phenomenon that is very important, which has been the subject of discussion but which at the same time is laid down as a basic principle by the Geneva Convention. It is the right to family reunification, the fact that a person who has arrived in France has the right to bring his family. So this right is laid down in the Convention on Human Rights. And this is a right that is currently unassailable and that is difficult to reconcile with migration policies in the framework that states would like to make of this migration policy. Here is the reading of what I could see and understand.

cleaned_comment: I would like to say something to Sören. The main problem with all immigrants is the languages. And I see this again and again, there are families, Turks have four, five, six children. The mother stays at home and raises her children. The children don't learn a word of German until the age of six. Or hardly any German. Then they are supposed to start school and they fail in school. And thus the slippery slope is set. And this has been recognized much too late. In principle, the children have to play with the German children. And that is unfortunately not wanted by the Turks either. Also with the kindergartens. That is not enough, if for example in Berlin, there are areas, that are 50% Turks, 50% Germans. And then the Turks are together and the Germans are together and in kindergarten the Turks don't learn enough German either. That is the main obstacle to getting close to the people and even starting a discussion with them. But work is now being done on this in Germany. But this has only been the case for a year or two, and we hope that this will help us get a grip on the problem. As far as crime is concerned, this is a sociological problem. A well-educated Turk or Muslim is no more a criminal than a German. The crime rate is basically the same. Then I wanted to say something to Antonia about you. I work in China and in Arab countries. These are two worlds. The Chinese are much, much poorer, they really have nothing. The Arabs, on the other hand, still live in wealth. And I have Chinese women at home all the time, they are incredibly ambitious from the start. They go to the adult education center, learn German, and then go to the hospitals because I'm a doctor. I can mediate that. They stay there for a year, go back to China and pass on their knowledge there. With the Chinese, it is possible to have excellent cooperation. If you say you start work at 8, they are there at 8. I have never managed to say in a hospital in Yemen, I start at 8 o'clock. The boss comes at 11. And there are 30 patients sitting outside, and I treat them with a nurse. But when they ask the boss and say, "tomorrow we start at 8 o'clock, perhaps a quarter past eight," he doesn't come until 10 o'clock. He just doesn't feel like it at all. I have found that it is very difficult to make an appointment with them and then to follow through with organizations. The mentality of Muslims is completely different from that of the Chinese and Europeans. And they are not dumber, the Muslims or the Yemenis. They just have a completely different structure than we do. I don't know why that is. But it is certainly a difficult population group. I know about the Africans from Sudan. They can also work well together with them. However, I must also say that I have mostly worked with Christian-oriented people. And there I also worked with an ophthalmologist who had worked there for a long time. But you always have to stand behind them and always drive them. And I would say, I'm heading for another problem now. We must not pull people out of these Muslim countries, China and African countries. But we have to go into those countries and raise their standard of living. Because they alone are not able to do it. The Chinese can do it. They are raising their standard of living. In the last ten years, as long as I have been there, their standard of living has risen enormously. In China, there is a great economic upswing; in Yemen, that is not the case. And also as I've noted, I've also been to Morocco, tourism is booming there, but they don't have their own industry. Yemen doesn't produce cooking pots, it doesn't produce telephones, it doesn't produce clothing, it doesn't produce anything. It's all imported from China. No industry at all. There are hardly any schools there. 50% are illiterate, in Morocco it is similarly high. And if they go to school and have learned something, there is no education of the students. Vocational training like in our country, nobody learns the profession of a carpenter, or then the next problem is, if they have learned something in English or German or American schools, then they study in Europe and then they stay in Europe and don't go back. That's a very big problem. They have a tremendous loss of their intelligence. Only, just the weak ones stay back there.
speech: [40:37] ich möchte zu Sören etwas sagen. Das Hauptproblem bei allen Immigranten sind die Sprachen. Und zwar ich sehe das immer wieder, da sind die Familien, haben die Türken vier, fünf, sechs Kinder. Die Mutter bleibt zuhause, erzieht ihre Kinder. Die Kinder lernen bis zum sechsten Lebensjahr kein Wort Deutsch. Oder kaum Deutsch. Dann sollen sie in die Schule kommen und versagen in der Schule. Und damit ist die schiefe Ebene gebahnt. Und das ist viel zu spät erkannt worden. Die Kinder müssen im Prinzip mit den deutschen Kindern spielen. Und das wird aber auch von den Türken leider nicht gewollt. Auch mit den Kindergärten. Das reicht nicht aus, wenn beispielsweise in Berlin, da gibt es Gegenden, das sind 50% Türken, 50% Deutsche. Und dann sind die Türken zusammen und die Deutschen zusammen und im Kindergarten lernen die Türken auch nicht  genügend Deutsch. Das ist das Haupthindernis, dass man an die Menschen herankommt und mit ihnen überhaupt eine Diskussion anfängt. Aber da wird inzwischen in Deutschland daran gearbeitet. Aber das ist erst seit einem oder zwei Jahren so und wir hoffen, dass wir damit das Problem in den Griff bekommen. Zur Kriminalität: das ist ein soziologisches Problem. Ein gut ausgebildeter Türke oder Muslim, der ist genau so wenig kriminell wie ein Deutscher. Die Kriminalität ist im Prinzip gleich. Dann wollte ich noch Antonia zu dir etwas sagen. Ich arbeite in China und in arabischen Ländern. Das sind zwei Welten. Die Chinesen sind viel, viel ärmer, die haben wirklich nichts. Da wohnen die Araber noch im Reichtum dagegen. Und ich habe immer wieder Chinesinnen bei uns zuhause, die sind von vornherein, die sind unglaublich strebsam. Die gehen in die Volkshochschule, lernen Deutsch, gehen dann in die Krankenhäuser, weil ich Arzt bin. Ich kann das vermitteln. Bleiben dort ein Jahr, gehen nach China zurück und vermitteln dort ihre Kenntnisse. Mit den Chinesen ist eine ganz hervorragende Kooperation möglich. Wenn man sagt, man fange um 8 an zu arbeiten, dann sind sie um 8 Uhr da. Ich habe es niemals geschafft, in einem Krankenhaus in Jemen zu sagen, ich fange um 8 Uhr an. Der Chef kommt um 11. Und draussen sitzen 30 Patienten, die ich dann mit einer Krankenschwester behandle. Aber wenn sie den Chef bitten und sagen: „tomorrow we start at 8 o’clock, perhaps a quarter past eight“, der kommt nicht vor 10 Uhr. Der hat einfach gar keine Lust. Ich habe festgestellt, es ist ganz ganz schwierig mit denen eine Verabredung zu treffen und dann auch Organisationen durchzuziehen. Die Mentalität der Muslime ist eine völlig andere als der Chinesen und der Europäer. Und die sind auch nicht dümmer, die Muslime oder die Jemeniten. Sie sind nur völlig anders strukturiert als wir. Woran das liegt, weiss ich auch nicht. Aber es ist sicherlich eine schwierige Bevölkerungsgruppe. Mit den Afrikanern weiss ich’s aus dem Sudan. Mit denen können sie auch gut zusammen arbeiten. Ich muss allerdings auch sagen, ich habe da meistens mit christlich orientierten zusammen gearbeitet. Und dort auch mit einer Augenärztin zusammen, die dort lange gearbeitet hat, das geht mit denen. Aber man muss immer dahinter stehen und immer sie treiben. Und ich würde sagen, ich steuere jetzt ein anderes Problem an. Wir dürfen aus diesen muslimischen Ländern, China und den afrikanischen Ländern keine Leute abziehen. Sondern wir müssen in diese Länder gehen und denen den Lebensstandard heben. Denn die alleine sind nicht in der Lage. Die Chinesen können das. Die heben ihren Lebensstandard. Der ist in den letzten zehn Jahren, solange bin ich dort, gewaltig gestiegen. In China ist ein grosser wirtschaftlicher Aufschwung, in Jemen ist das nicht der Fall. Und auch so wie ich es festgestellt habe, ich bin auch in Marokko gewesen, da boomt der Tourismus, aber sie haben keine eigene Industrie. Der Jemen produziert keine Kochtöpfe, kein Telefon, keine Kleidung, kein gar nichts. Das wird alles aus China importiert. Überhaupt keine eigene Industrie. Dort gibt es kaum Schulen. 50% sind Analphabeten, in Marokko ist es ähnlich hoch. Und wenn sie zur Schule gehen und haben etwas gelernt, es gibt keine Ausbildung der Schüler. Berufsausbildung wie bei uns, da lernt keiner den Beruf Schreiner, oder dann ist das nächste Problem, wenn sie auf englischen oder deutschen oder Amerikanischen Schulen etwas gelernt haben, dann studieren sie in Europa und dann bleiben sie in Europa und gehen nicht wieder zurück. cleaned_comment: Yes, I think I should clarify again, I'm from Spain. As I said, we have experienced a sharp increase in unemployment within a few months, to 15, now to 18 percent even in some regions of the country. We also have a responsibility; I think that must also be clear; to humanity, I would say. We have to make sure, of course, that we maintain our standard of living, but we also have to find a way out. All people in the world have the right to eat, to feed themselves, to educate their children. I think we have enough possibilities here in Europe to deal with immigration, yes? And at the same time we have to make sure that the countries of origin of the immigrants can develop further; economically, but also culturally and socially. It is also a question of solidarity between continents, between countries. As I said, we should perhaps remember what Andalusia, my region, was like eight centuries ago. There was a lot of immigration, later also emigration - and I think that nobody leaves his home country for fun, but people do it out of need, because they have nothing left to survive. Hardly anything to eat. They don't necessarily do it voluntarily. So life has to be very bad, it has to be very bad for people to decide to leave their home country and that there is no prospect of improvement, that things cannot be improved in the short term in the country. I think we have to make sure that there is a greater balance between the different regions of the world. And I would also like to point out the following: Everyone has their own language and their own culture; these must also be respected and protected. I would also like to ensure that each individual is allowed to keep and cultivate his or her own language and culture. So you should make sure that everyone gets along, right? No matter what opinion we have of the other. Well, in today's time, back then, I was talking about the time 800 years ago. When, in my region of Andalusia, very different peoples, very different religions got along well with each other, that is, the Muslims, the Christians, the Jews, there was a great harmony, that has been lost. We have to try to get along with each other again, to understand each other, otherwise we won't achieve anything. And if we do not understand this situation, then we will not understand the 27 states that make up the European Union today. And only when we succeed in doing that, we will find a way out. Not necessarily in the capitals, that's how I see the problem of declining voter turnout, which is also due to the economic situation, but also to these social grievances. So if we want to achieve something, I think we have to find another way. Immigration is something we have to accept, it has to be legalized. We have to create precautions for it, find ways. cleaned_comment: I am very divided about what I heard, because I think that for immigration, there was a time after the war when we had to build a lot of things. I'm in the energy sector and we had to draw very high voltage lines, we had to create railroads, we had to do a lot of things. And I think that at that time, we were very happy to find people who came to work, to integrate, to create wealth. So I think that immigration does not have the same meaning and the same stakes at one time compared to another. And already I think in fact it is the time that is important in my eyes. And now I would like to say that I think that it is not necessarily obvious to want to integrate people at all costs. I think that it doesn't work if there is no will. I'm talking about the principle that we all know more or less the work environment. I think that we live in a time when it is very difficult, when we see people who have done higher education, who have a bachelor's degree and then a master's degree, and who cannot find a job. I can't understand that someone who comes from somewhere else, who after three, four, five years, who doesn't have a diploma, who doesn't speak the language of the country, I can't see how they can be integrated. This is my point of view. Now, this may be part of a small minority, but I think that we should not make a... I think that integration can only be successful if the person himself has the desire to integrate. And that, I think that, to answer Brigitte, I think that there is no problem to have people come when financially or culturally, that seems to me less important, but financially, it is necessary to be able to make live in a home, to create wealth, to bring things to a country, that seems to me completely legitimate. We can see that in the last thirty or forty years, there are people who have come and worked in sectors where we did not feel like going. We can see that, to give a precise example, it's the cleaning companies, the metro, we can see that. So, no problem there. On the other hand, I think that the problem comes when these people arrive and who, apart from the culture, have difficulty integrating precisely because there is no will to learn the language and afterwards, to be able to look for work, to prepare diplomas etc. I think that the problem comes from the fact that they have to learn the language and to be able to work. I think that's where the problem comes from. But I think that someone who wants to integrate, I imagine that in European countries, these are not very atypical lifestyles, and I think that if someone wants to integrate, working and living between di and mi[?] like everyone else, I think that it doesn't impose a huge problem.

cleaned_comment: Yes hello, I'm from Andalusia. I hope that everybody understands me because in Andalusia we speak a little bit different Spanish. That's why I try to speak a little bit slower. So, I would like to start with the immigration issue. I think we are not always completely honest about that. We try to discuss it, but often the issue of immigration is not really discussed through. And that's sometimes like a torpedo. For example, the immigration issue is also exploited by employers. Often immigrants are exploited by employers for moonlighting, because that is often the only way for these immigrants to earn their bread at all. I think that immigration, no matter how far the immigration goes, must be legalized in any case. All immigrants living in a country really need to get papers, they need to be dealt with honestly. If, for example, they can't get a work contract because they don't have papers, then that's just not possible, otherwise they're just exploited. And there is really no other way than being honest with them. We really have always had a lot of immigration in Europe. Immigrants were always needed to do the work because there were too few workers and I think that must always be taken into account. We have workers, we also have smart workers and that's why I think that the labor force has to be distributed very simply and correctly. I come from a region where you see a lot of immigrants coming by boat; you always see it on the news that a lot of immigrants come by boat, but a lot of them come by plane. I think that there must be united policies in the whole of Europe. What we don't want is a Europe only for profit, for profit and every time there is a problem, yes then we divide again. No, a united Europe. Immigration and the problems of immigration are a very heavy human problem and very deep problem and I think that we all have experienced waves of immigration everywhere and at some point it can also hit us and that's when it's also the case that we definitely have to show solidarity as well. Of course, this is not easy, but I think that we have to make sure that this issue is properly addressed at the level of the European Parliament, so that honesty finally comes into politics. We don't want hypocritical politicians. Not every time there are European elections that no one cares. Why is no one actually interested in the European elections? That is quite clear, we really want to make sure that the right decisions are made, because we really want to make sure that the right European parliamentarians are elected. That's why we all have to participate, these are really important issues that exist here and that's really very important, because it's probably not good that you always hear from politicians that everything that's good comes from their own country and everything that's bad is decided in Brussels. We have to assume that common policies are really made here in Brussels, and we really have to give the European Parliament the right power. Immigration policy is of course also linked to foreign policy. There is also the issue of climate change, of course, but all these issues should not divide the European countries, of course. We must not have a situation where we just say we are the best. No we have to move on, we can't just look at what's happening in America.
speech: [22:00] Ja hallo, ich komme aus Andalusien. Ich hoffe, dass mich alle verstehen, weil in Andalusien sprechen wir ein bisschen ein anderes Spanisch. Deswegen versuch ich ja auch etwas langsamer zu sprechen. So, ich möchte also anfangen was das Thema Einwanderung betrifft. Ich denke, da sind wir nicht immer ganz ehrlich. Wir versuchen, darüber zu diskutieren, aber oft wird das Thema der Einwanderung nicht richtig durchdiskutiert. Und das ist manchmal wie ein Torpedo. Das Thema der Einwanderung wird zum Beispiel auch von den Arbeitgebern ausgenutzt. Oft werden die Einwanderer ausgenutzt von den Arbeitgebern für Schwarzarbeit, das ist nämlich oft die einzige Möglichkeit für diese Einwanderer überhaupt sich ihr Brot zu verdienen. Ich denke, dass Einwanderung, egal wie weit die Einwanderung geht, auf jeden Fall legalisiert werden muss. Alle Einwanderer, die in einem Land leben, müssen wirklich Papiere bekommen, da muss endlich ehrlich mit denen umgegangen werden. Wenn sie zum Beispiel keinen Arbeitsvertrag bekommen können, weil sie keine Papiere haben, dann ist das ja wohl nicht möglich, anders werden sie nur ausgenutzt. Und anders ist es wirklich nicht anders als ehrlich ihnen gegenüber. Wir haben ja wirklich auch immer viele Einwanderung in Europa gehabt. Es wurden immer Einwanderer gebraucht um die Arbeit zu verrichten weil zu wenig Arbeiter da waren und ich denke, dass muss immer auch berücksichtigt werden. Wir haben Arbeiter, wir haben auch schlaue Arbeiter und deswegen denke ich, dass die Arbeitskraft ganz einfach und richtig verteilt werden muss. Ich komme aus einer Region wo man sehr viele Einwanderer zwar mit den Booten sieht; man sieht das ja auch immer in den Nachrichten, dass sehr viele Einwanderer mit dem Schiff kommen; aber sehr viele kommen mit dem Flugzeug. Ich denke, dass das einfach auch vereinte Politiken geben muss in ganz Europa. Was wir nicht wollen ist ein Europa nur für den Gewinn, für den Profit und jedes Mal, wenn es ein Problem ist, ja dann teilen wir uns wieder. Nein, ein gemeinsames Europa. Einwanderung und die Probleme der Einwanderung sind ein sehr schweres menschliches Problem und sehr tiefgreifendes Problem und ich denke, dass wir alle überall Einwanderungswellen erlebt haben und irgendwann kann das auch uns treffen und da ist es dann auch so, dass wir auf jeden Fall auch Solidarität zeigen müssen. Das ist natürlich nicht einfach, aber ich denke doch dass wir auf jeden Fall dafür sorgen müssen, dass auf Ebene des europäischen Parlamentes dieses Thema richtig angegangen wird, damit endlich mal auch Ehrlichkeit auch in die Politik kommt. Wir wollen keine scheinheiligen Politiker. Nicht jedes Mal wenn es Europawahlen gibt dass sich niemand darum kümmert. Warum interessiert sich eigentlich niemand für die Europawahlen? Das ist ganz klar, wir wollen wirklich dafür sorgen, dass die richtigen Entscheidungen getroffen werden, denn wir wollen wirklich dafür sorgen, dass auch die richtigen Europaparlamentarier gewählt werden. Deswegen müssen wir uns alle daran beteiligen, das sind wirklich wichtige Themen, die hier bestehen und dass ist wirklich ganz wichtig, denn es ist ja wohl nicht gut, dass man immer von den Politikern hört, dass alles was gut ist, kommt aus dem eigenen Land und alles was schlecht ist, wird in Brüssel beschlossen. Wir müssen davon ausgehen, dass wirklich auch gemeinsame Politiken hier in Brüssel gemacht werden und da müssen wir dann auch wirklich auch dem Europaparlament die richtige Macht geben. Auch die Einwanderungspolitik hängt natürlich mit der Aussenpolitik zusammen. Da gibt es natürlich auch die Frage des Klimawandels, aber all diese Fragen sollen natürlich nicht die europäischen Länder teilen. Wir dürfen keine Situation, wo wir einfach nur sagen, wir sind die Besten. Nein wir müssen weitermachen, wir können uns nicht einfach nur ansehen, was in Amerika passiert. [27:04]

cleaned_comment: Yes, in fact I note that - the question rather that I ask myself is, at the moment to integrate the countries in the European Union, on subjects as important and as strong as immigration or in the same way what we will see later on global warming, I wonder about the fact of building a Europe that is bigger and bigger in surface, in countries, in member states, which leads to a diversity of important opinions as well as the mathematical greeting, we are fifteen around the table and it is necessarily more difficult to agree with fifteen than with two or three.
